reasoning: Cruciality is high because whether power concentrates strongly determines whether the paper’s “partial AM-convergence + trade” pathway is even available, shifting strategy between broad pluralistic institution-building vs targeting a tiny set of pivotal actors. Paper-specificity is solid: the question is explicitly about §3.5’s ‘concentration of power’ blocker and about making the ≥1-in-a-million AM-converged minority irrelevant, though ‘power concentration after AGI’ is also a common governance question outside this paper. Tractability is moderate-low: we can make partial progress via political-economy modeling (returns to scale in compute/capital, security advantage, institutional scenarios), analogies to past general-purpose technologies, and empirical work on compute supply chains and state capacity, but deep post-AGI forecasting is highly uncertain and definition-sensitive. Clarity is fairly good but key terms (“post-AGI period,” “nearly all resources,” and what threshold makes AM-convergence ‘functionally irrelevant’) need operationalization. Decision hook is excellent and explicitly bifurcates strategies. Dead weight is minimal; most text sharpens scope and stakes.
title: Power concentration threshold for partial AM-convergence relevance
